description: Armenia's official memorial dedicated to the 1.5 million victims of the Armenian genocide, built in 1967 on Tsitsernakaberd hill. The complex spans 4,500 square meters and includes the Memorial Wall, Sanctuary of Eternity with eternal flame, and the 44-meter Reborn Armenia column symbolizing national rebirth.
highlights: Twelve slabs positioned in circle representing twelve lost provinces
Eternal flame at 1.5 meters depth honoring 1.5 million victims
100-meter memorial wall listing towns and villages where massacres occurred
Museum built into hillside with three main halls and over 1,000 square meters
Every April 24, thousands gather for Armenian Genocide Remembrance Day
tips: Museum closed Mondays, open other days
Guided tours available in English, French, German, Russian (AMD 7,000-10,000)
Take ride-hailing app (AMD 600) or taxi (AMD 800-1,200) from city center
Allow time for reflection - this is a deeply moving experience
No admission fee for the complex
vibe: Profoundly solemn and emotionally powerful, a place of remembrance that honors the past while affirming the resilience and survival of the Armenian people
